metadata.title: Autophagy Genes Enhance Murine Gammaherpesvirus 68 Reactivation from Latency by Preventing Virus-Induced Systemic Inflammation

abstract.text: MHV68 WUMS (ATCC VR1465) was used for all infections and is hereafter referred to as wild-type MHV68. M3FL-MHV68, which expresses firefly luciferase driven by the viral M3 promoter (Hwang et al., 2008) was used to study in vivo replication. For virus-specific T cell assays, MHV68 expressing SIINFEKL peptide from ovalbumin (ova-MHV68) was used (Braaten et al., 2005; Loh et al., 2012) .

Bone marrow derived macrophages (BMDMs) were generated as follows: Bone marrow was flushed out with NB-10 medium (Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium, 10% fetal bovine serum, 5% horse serum, 10% CMG14-12(Takeshita et al., 2000),1 mM sodium pyruvate, 2 mM L-glutamine, 1x MEM nonessential amino acids) and cells were plated on non-TC treated plates (BD Biosciences, 351029). On day 7, cells were counted for plating. MHV68 was passaged in NIH 3T12 cells as published previously (Clambey et al., 2000) . For viral growth curves, BMDMs were plated at 1x10 5 cells/well in 24-well plate and on day 11, were infected with MHV68 at a MOI of 0.05 or 5 PFU/cell for 1 h at 37°C. For each time point, plates were frozen at -80°C for subsequent plaque assay viral titration.

body_text.text: Homogenized tissue or frozen viral supernatants were serially diluted in D5 medium (DMEM, 5% FBS, 2 mM Lglutamine, 1 mM HEPES) and applied to NIH 3T12 monolayers for 1 h at 37°C. Samples were overlaid with 2% methylcellulose in DMEM supplemented with 5% FBS and incubated at 37°C. On day six, 3% neutral red in PBS was added to visualize plaques. The limit of detection for this assay is 50 PFU.

Male mice were infected with 1x10 6 PFU per mouse, i.p with M3FL-MHV68. D-luciferin (Sigma) was reconstituted to a concentration of 15 mg/ml in PBS and stored at -80C until use. To image mice, D-luciferin solution was injected in mice i.p. at a dose of 150 mg/kg and mice were placed back into cages for five minutes. The mice were anesthetized in a 2.5-3.5% isoflurane chamber for three to five minutes and placed on the imaging chamber, positioned such that there was continuous flow of isoflurane into the nose cones during imaging. Bioluminescence imaging of M3FL-MHV68-infected mice was collected on the Xenogen IVIS 200 system (Caliper Life Sciences), and data collection and analysis were done on the Living Image software (Caliper Life Sciences) by selecting a region of interest and measuring the total flux and average radiance.
body_text.section: Bioluminescence Imaging of Mice Using M3FL-MHV68

body_text.text: PECs or splenocytes were stained for live cells (Live/Dead Fixable Aqua, Invitrogen) and with the following antibodies: CD3e (clone 145-2C11), CD4 (clone RM4-5), CD8a (clone 53-6.7), CD19 (clone 6D5), CD64 (clone X54-5/7.1), MHC H-2Kb (clone AF6-88.5), MHC I-A/E (clone M5/114.15.2), NK1.1 (clone PK136), CD11c (clone N418), CD11b (clone M1/70), MerTK (R&D Systems, BAF591), F4/80 (clone BM8), Ly6G (clone IA8), Ly6C (clone HK1.4), CD80 (clone 16-10A1), CD86 (clone GL-1). For intracellular cytokine analyses, cells were incubated for five hours with Brefeldin A and monensin. After surface staining, cells were fixed and permeabilized using BD Cytofix/Cytoperm (BD Biosciences, 554714) and stained for IFN-γ (clone XMG1.2) or iNOS (clone CXNFT). All flow cytometry data were collected on LSR Fortessa (BD Biosciences) and analyzed using Flowjo 10.1 (Tree Star).
body_text.section: Immune Populations and Intracellular Protein Analysis

body_text.text: Tissue samples were homogenized with 1.0mm silica beads on the mini BeadBeater (Biospec) and RNA was extracted using Trizol (Ambion). PECs were flushed out of mice using 8 ml of D10 media (DMEM, 10% FBS, 2 mM L-glutamine, 1 mM HEPES, 1% NEAA) and washed once with D10 media. 5x10 6 PECs were plated on a TC treated plate for at least 24 hours at 37°C to allow macrophages to adhere. Cells were washed with PBS and RNA was extracted using RNEasy Mini kit (Qiagen). cDNA synthesis using ImProm II (Promega) was performed. Real time qPCR using SYBR Green was performed for the specified targets, using actin as an internal control. Primers used were β-actin (5'-GCTCCTTCGTTGCCGGTCCA-3' and 5'-TTGCACATGCCGGAGCCGTT-3'), Nos2 (5'-GTTCTCAGCCCAACAATACAAGA-3' and 5'-GTGGACGGGTCGATGTCAC-3'), Tnf (5'-TGGCCTCCCTCTCATCAGTTC-3' and 5'-GCTACAGGCTTGTCACTCGAATTTT-3'), Il1b (5'-GCACACCCACCCTGCAG-3' and 5'-AACCGTTTTTCCATCTTCTTCTT-3'), Mx1 (5'-TCTGAGGAGAGCCAGACGAT-3' and 5'-ACTCTGGTCCCCAATGACAG-3') and
Oasl2 (5'-GGATGCCTGGGAGAGAATCG-3' and 5'-TCGCCTGCTCTTCGAAAC TG-3'). Transcript levels were analyzed using the ΔΔCT method, with β-actin as the reference gene.

mRNA was extracted from cell lysates by means of oligo-dT beads (Invitrogen). For cDNA synthesis, we used custom oligo-dT primer with a barcode and adaptor-linker sequence (CCTACACGACGCTCTTCCGATCT-XXXXXXXX-T15). After first-strand synthesis, samples were pooled together based on Actb qPCR values and RNA-DNA hybrid was degraded with consecutive acid-alkali treatment. Then, a second sequencing linker (AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGTCTG) was ligated with T4 ligase (NEB) followed by SPRI clean-up. The mixture then was PCR enriched 12 cycles and SPRI purified to yield final strand-specific RNA-seq libraries. Libraries were sequenced using HiSeq 2500 (Illumina) using 50bpX25bp pair-end sequencing. Second mate was used for sample demultiplexing. Reads were aligned to the GRCm38.p2 assembly of mouse genome using STAR aligner. Additional options were "--outFilterMultimapNmax 15 --outFilterMismatchNmax 6 --quantMode TranscriptomeSAM". Aligned reads were quantified using quant3p script (github.com/ctlab/quant3p) to account for specifics of 3' sequencing: higher dependency on good 3' annotation and lower level of sequence specificity close to 3' end. RefSeq genome annotation was used. Using MACS2 peak caller around 70000 putative exons were identified (peaks in rnaseq alignment not overlapping with known exons). Around 6600 of them were assigned to a gene located within 5000 bp and added into annotation. For on average 1 million reads per sample that mapped to multiple genome positions there were only one exonic alignment. For these reads multimapper flags were removed for read counting purposes. Actual read counting were carried out by ht-seq with enriched genome annotation and alignment with fixed multimapper flags. DESeq2 was used for differential gene expression analysis which was used as ranked list in pre-ranked GSEA analysis to identify pathway enrichments. RNA-seq data were deposited to the European Nucleotide Archive under the accession number PRJEB10074. (A) PECs from naïve or latently-infected mice were stained for various surface markers and analyzed by flow cytometry. Data were combined from three independent biological replicate experiments. Each point represents a single mouse and data were analyzed by two-way ANOVA with Sidak's multiple comparisons post-test. Only significant comparisons are indicated. *p<0.05, **p<0.01 (B) Transcript levels of the indicated genes were measured in latently infected peritoneal macrophages from Atg5 f/f and Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice and were normalized to β-actin using ∆∆C T method for quantitation. Statistical significance was analyzed by non-parametric Mann-Whitney test. ***p<0.005, ****p <0.001 (C) Gene set enrichment analysis was performed on RNA-seq data from naïve and latent adherent peritoneal macrophages from Atg16l1 f/f and Atg16l1 f/f -LysMcre mice.

(D) Mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) of iNOS in peritoneal macrophages (F4/80 -hi , CD11b -hi ) of Atg5 f/f and Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice 28 days after infection using flow cytometry. Each point represents a single mouse and data are analyzed by the non-parametric Mann-Whitney U test. **p <0.01 (E) PECs from Atg5 f/f and Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice were treated with 10 ng/ml recombinant murine IFN-γ for 36 hours. Cells were stained for intracellular iNOS protein and measured by flow cytometry. MFI of iNOS was measured in peritoneal macrophages (F4/80 -hi , CD11b -hi ) and iNOS + gate set was set based on the intracellular stain using an isotype control. Each point represents a single mouse and data were analyzed the non-parametric Mann-Whitney U test comparing the two genotypes within each treatment group. **p <0.01
body_text.section: Adoptive Transfer of gp150 and OT-I T Cells and Intracellular IFN-γ Production Assays

BIBREF0.title: 000 PECs pooled from Atg5 f/f or Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice were plated onto a monolayer of MEFs for 24 h in a 96-well plate in the presence of 10 μg/ml anti-IFN-γ or control antibody to check efficiency of neutralization by ELISA. The data are two biological replicate experiments with 24 technical replicate wells per sample. Each point is a technical replicate and data were analyzed by a one-way ANOVA

BIBREF1.title: The presence of preformed virions in latent cells were tested by disrupting PECs and splenocytes using 0.5 mm silica beads for 1 min, twice and subsequently plated in limiting dilutions as previously described in Figure S1. Experiments were repeated three times, with three to five mice pooled per experiment

BIBREF2.title: An optimized CD8+ T-cell response controls productive and latent gammaherpesvirus infection

BIBREF3.title: Disruption of the murine gammaherpesvirus 68 M1 open reading frame leads to enhanced reactivation from latency

BIBREF4.title: Cutting edge: activation of virus-specific CD4 T cells throughout gamma-herpesvirus latency

BIBREF5.title: Persistent gammaherpesvirus replication and dynamic interaction with the host in vivo

BIBREF6.title: Specific mutation of a gammaherpesvirus-expressed antigen in response to CD8 T cell selection in vivo

BIBREF7.title: Identification and Characterization of the New Osteoclast Progenitor with Macrophage Phenotypes Being Able to Differentiate into Mature Osteoclasts
BIBREF7.venue: Journal of Bone and Mineral Research

FIGREF0.text: Thy1.1 CD4 T cells(Freeman et al., 2011) and OT-I CD8-Thy1.1 T cells from the splenocytes were transferred i.v. into naive Atg5 f/f and Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice one day before infection with ova-MHV68. Mice were infected with 1x10 6 PFU/mouse i.p. for 28 days. Isolated PECs were stimulated with 2 uM gp150 peptide (LSNNNPTTIMRPPVAQN) or 1 μg/ml ovalbumin (SIINFEKL) or a nonspecific peptide (Flu NP 366-374 ) for 5 h at 37°C in the presence of Brefeldin A (Biolegend, 420601) and Monensin (Biolegend, 420701). Thy1.1 + T cells (CD4 + TcrVβ12 + Vα11.1/11.2 + for gp150, CD8 + MHC I tetramer for Ova for OT-I) were stained for intracellular IFN-γ and analyzed on LSR Fortessa (BD Biosciences). Virus Reactivation from Splenocytes was Not Detected in Mice after 42 Days of Virus Infection, Related toFigure 1(A) All Atg f/f -LysMcre and wild-type littermates were infected with 1x10 6 PFU MHV68 intraperitoneally (i.p.) for 42 days to determine frequency of virus reactivation in splenocytes during latent infection using LDA analysis. Only the graph for Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice is shown for representation. Data points indicate the percentage of wells that were positive for cytopathic effect (CPE) on a mouse embryonic fibroblast (MEF) monolayer at a given cell dilution.(B) The presence of preformed virions in latent cells were tested by disrupting PECs and splenocytes using 0.5 mm silica beads for 1 min, twice and subsequently plated in limiting dilutions similar to (A). All LDA experiments are N=3 or 4 with three to five mice pooled per experiment. Data are the mean +/-SEM and p-values were obtained by paired t-test over all dilutions. Only significant comparisons are indicated. ****p <0.Immune Cell Analysis in the Peritoneum of Latent Atg5 f/f -LysMcre Mice, Related toFigure 4

FIGREF1.text: Peritoneal T cells, not NK cells, are the major source of IFN-γ in the peritoneum during latent infection, Related to Figure 6 (A) NK cells were depleted in Atg5 f/f and Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice using α-NK1.

FIGREF2.text: Neutralization of IFN-γ in Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice infected for 28 days rescues reactivation of virus in the peritoneum, Related to Figure 7 (A) LDA analysis of Atg5 f/f and Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice infected after 28 days with MHV68. LDA experiment was repeated three times, with three to five mice pooled per experiment. Data are the mean +/-SEM and p-values were obtained by paired t-test over all dilutions. ****p <0.001 (B) Atg5 f/f and Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice were infected for 28 days. PECs were isolated in the presence of 10 μg/ml anti-IFN-γ antibody and virus reactivation in PECs was measured ex vivo in the presence of anti-IFN-γ antibody. Data were combined from two biological experiments with three mice pooled per experiment and represented with the

TABREF0.text: technical replicate wells per sample. Each data point represents a technical replicate and analyzed by the non-parametric Mann-Whitney U test. No significant differences were observed.(C)  Mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) of co-stimulatory molecules CD80 and CD86, and MHC Class II (I-A/E) in peritoneal macrophages (F4/80 -hi , CD11b -hi ) of Atg5 f/f and Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice 28 days after infection is shown using flow cytometry. Each point represents a single mouse and data are analyzed by the non-parametric Mann-Whitney U test. No significant differences were observed. (D) gp150 CD4 or (E) OT-I CD8 T cells were transferred i.v. into naive Atg5 f/f and Atg5 f/f -LysMcre mice, which were infected with Ova peptide expressing MHV68 for 28 days. Transferred T cells from the peritoneum were stained for intracellular IFN-γ without stimulation, stimulation with a nonspecific peptide (Flu NP 366-374 ), or with specific peptide (gp150 or Ova) for 5 h ex vivo. Absolute cell counts and percentage of T cells graphed. Data were combined from three independent biological replicate experiments. Each point represents a single mouse and data are analyzed by the non-parametric Mann-Whitney U test. No significant differences were observed.
